definition:
If $\kappa$ is a cardinal then a set $C\subseteq\kappa$ is *closed* iff
for any $S\subseteq C$ and $\alpha<\kappa$, $\sup(S\cap \alpha)=\alpha$
then $\alpha\in C$. (That is, if the limit of some sequence in $C$ is
less than $\kappa$ then the limit is also in $C$.)

If $\kappa$ is a cardinal and $C\subseteq\kappa$ then $C$ is *unbounded*
if, for any $\alpha<\kappa$, there is some $\beta\in C$ such that
$\alpha<\beta$.

If a set is both closed and unbounded then it is a *club* set.
